messageBody:
>So said Vladimir Ritz Bossicard on 2003-08-08 --------------------
>> I'm unhappy about the small number of unit tests being written here and
>> would like my colleagues to write more tests.
>
>IMO you first need to convince developers that they must write tests
>before showing them how good (or bad) the coverage is.
>
>Normal and not test-infected developers will say that "no, there's no
>bug in my code!" so it's up to you to show that:
>
>1) these bugs exist
>2) they are easy to reproduce (half the work done)
>3) once a test is written, it's executed over and over again (no need to
>look at printlns output)
>
>How to spot potential bugs? Try to use PMD and look out for unused code
>(parameters and variables). A paper from Stanford pointed out that the
>cause of bugs is often "silly" mistakes (like unused code).

Another thing you can do is invite yourself into the next debugging session and write tests rather than grope around with println(). When the problem is fixed, be sure to say, "At least *that* will never happen again."

Or invite someone to help you with your next debugging session, if you have any.

Take care.
